<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
RECAP
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/23/the-inflation-situation-how-we-got-here?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
The Inflation Situation: How We Got Here
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/23/the-inflation-situation-how-we-got-here?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Balloons holding up money " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/5d34b1dbb67b208244ef43a9ba72db2587dc3006-1500x1000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba </em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The funny thing about the current inflation scare is...it all happened so <em>abruptly</em>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As the first Covid wave ripped through the US last spring, more than 20 million Americans lost their jobs and the country entered its worst recession in history. With GDP <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/19/its-official-the-covid-recession-lasted-just-two-months-the-shortest-in-us-history.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tumbling 31.4%</a> in Q2 2020, the last thing worrying economists was surging prices. After all, for a brief moment, oil prices had just plummeted below $0.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But it turns out the worst recession in US history was also the shortest—by far. Thanks to government stimulus to the tune of nearly $6 trillion, many Americans were able to weather the storm and, flush with cash but restricted to their homes, went full <em>Extreme Makeover</em>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Consider this: Consumer spending on goods was nearly <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/americans-spending-goods-versus-experiences-supply-chain-crisis-2021-10?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">26% higher</a> in August 2021 than in January 2019.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Demand is just one element of the price equation</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And while demand for goods skyrocketed, supply was not ready to meet it. For a number of reasons—frequent Covid lockdowns in Asia, widespread labor shortages, poor planning—producers were unable to make and ship enough goods to satisfy the ravenous appetites of consumers.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So given this severe demand–supply imbalance, prices started to climb, slowly at first in late 2020 but then really picking up steam as the ball dropped on 2021. The consumer price index, which monitors the prices of a basket of consumer goods, grew 1.7% annually in February but by May had <a href="https://www.bls.gov/charts/consumer-price-index/consumer-price-index-by-category-line-chart.htm?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">jumped 5%</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The higher inflation readings in spring 2021 were attributed to a few items that had an outsized impact on rising prices. You might remember all the fuss about used cars, which accounted for <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/12/inflation-rising-economy-weird?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">more than one-third</a> of the monthly price increases in June. This weird dynamic lent ammo to the officials, Fed Chair Jerome Powell included, who argued that inflation was “transitory” and likely to subside once a few pandemic wrinkles had been ironed out.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But Team Transitory is on the back foot right now. This fall, inflation has spread from used cars and energy to items across the economy, from rents to food to apparel. At the same time, wages are surging, which is great for workers but also contributes to inflation, as companies must raise prices on their products to offset higher labor costs.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In October, consumer prices rose at their fastest pace in 31 years, and economists are still debating when inflation will peak.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So that’s how we got here.</p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/23/why-is-inflation-bad?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Why Is Inflation...Bad?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/23/why-is-inflation-bad?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Why Is Inflation...Bad? " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=430 src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-11-24/image-efda587fa20d01d0069a32696b082c1d614e1ef6-398x255-gif/giph.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Why Is Inflation...Bad? " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-11-24/image-efda587fa20d01d0069a32696b082c1d614e1ef6-398x255-gif/giph.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em></em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Not a dumb question at all. In fact, many economists <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2021-11-16/higher-inflation-why-do-economists-dislike-it-so-much?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">have trouble</a> explaining exactly why inflation is so harmful.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Let’s start here: Inflation is <em>good</em>, when it grows slowly. The Fed targets a 2% rate of inflation over the long run, allowing for a few temporary blips.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Moderate inflation is a sign of a healthy economy. When consumers expect prices to increase in the future, they want to buy goods <em>now</em>. Producers take this demand as a sign that they should make more goods, hire more labor, make more investments, etc., which generates a “virtuous” cycle of growth.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>And while inflation does mean higher prices for consumers, it also leads to higher salaries, blunting its effects on your wallet.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Last quarter, wages </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/article/business-wages-salaries-increase-8ce98ea3bcc14c4810eb5a1111e1df49?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">jumped the most</a></span><span> in 20 years of record-keeping.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Okay, so when is inflation bad?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When higher prices outstrip wage growth, that’s bad, obviously, because your standard of living falls. Inflation is especially harmful to folks whose income is more fixed—like many seniors.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Inflation, when left unchecked, can also escalate quickly. As we mentioned before, inflation messes with the human brain. As workers grow concerned about rising prices, they push for higher wages, which in turn raises costs for businesses, which forces them to hike prices, and...lather, rinse, repeat. This is called the “wage–price spiral,” and it led to consumer prices rising more than 14% annually in 1980.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Finally, higher inflation is bad because it typically doesn’t end well. In a bid to stop the spiraling inflation of the 1970s, then-Fed Chair Paul Volcker cranked up interest rates to slow down the economy, a necessary action that inevitably resulted in a punishing recession.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As we’ll discuss a little later, current Fed leaders have a tough task ahead of them in trying to rein in inflation without hitting the brakes on economic growth.</p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
HISTORY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/23/a-quick-timeline-of-inflation-since-wwii?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
US Inflation Since WWII
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/23/a-quick-timeline-of-inflation-since-wwii?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="Chart of inflation in modern US history " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/050c9a60edff3e177bace17c673065c999967372-1100x690.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>The White House </em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">This chart from the White House shows the <a href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/cea/blog/2021/07/06/historical-parallels-to-todays-inflationary-episode/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">six major inflationary episodes</a> following World War II, as measured by the consumer price index (CPI) and personal consumption expenditures (PCE), which is the Fed’s preferred inflation gauge. Let’s briefly explore each episode.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">1946–1948: </strong>In the years following WWII, inflation jumped more than 20% due to the scrapping of wartime price controls, surging consumer demand, and supply shortages.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">1950–1951: </strong>The Korean War spurred a rush for goods, while some production pivoted back to military material.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">1969–1971: </strong>GDP growth averaged a whopping 4.8% during this period of economic expansion, which also resulted in higher inflation.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">1973–1982: </strong>Two shocks to energy markets (an OPEC oil embargo and conflicts in the Middle East) led to the longest stretch of inflation in US history.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">1989–1991: </strong>Another war in the Middle East, the Gulf War, caused gas prices to spike.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">2008: </strong>Oil prices jumped to $140/barrel in July 2008, double what they had been a year earlier. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What can we learn? </strong>While each inflationary period has its own unique characteristics, White House economists argue that our current situation most closely parallels the post-WWII bump in prices, which resulted from pent-up consumer demand and supply chain disruptions, and not 1970s-style inflation, which stemmed from extraordinary shocks to energy markets.</p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FED
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/23/what-should-the-fed-do-about-inflation?mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
What Should the Fed Do?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/23/what-should-the-fed-do-about-inflation?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}" style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" class="">
<img alt="A shoulders-up photo of Fed Chair Jerome Powell looking off into the distance" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/f87c5338c52518030d37448a3e4d66e036131908-6000x4000.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Sarah Silbiger/Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">With inflation at its highest level since 1990, pressure is <a href="https://apnews.com/article/business-economy-prices-inflation-jerome-powell-583029ed34f028d4950fd5b0d896388f?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">mounting</a> on the central bank to channel Mr. Freeze and cool down prices.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What would that look like? </strong>Winding down its pandemic-era stimulus measures more aggressively. The central bank has already started to taper the $120 billion/month in bond purchases it began last summer, but some economists, such as Harvard’s Jason Furman, think the Fed should <a href="https://www.piie.com/sites/default/files/documents/furman-2021-11-17.pdf?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">speed up</a> the wind-down in a bid to stop price growth in its tracks.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px"><li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Some Fed officials agree. St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said recently, “It makes sense to try to move a little bit more hawkishly here and try to manage the inflation risk.”</span></li></ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But it’s not that simple. Remember, the Fed changed its policy framework in 2020 that allows it to overshoot its 2% inflation target in the short term to achieve “maximum employment,” the idea that anyone who is willing and able to work has the opportunity to get a job.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And while the unemployment rate has dropped more quickly than expected (it’s down to 4.6% from a 14.7% peak in May 2020), the economy remains 5 million jobs short of its pre-pandemic levels.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So the Fed is in a <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-11-19/fed-s-powell-fights-high-inflation-in-his-1970-s-paul-volcker-moment?sref=vuYGislZ" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">really tricky position</a>. It knows people are anxious about inflation, but also that the labor market is not fully healed. Reducing its bond purchases more aggressively, then immediately hiking interest rates afterward, could slow the economy before it’s totally recovered.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Plus, there are signs that the supply chain crunch is beginning to ease, which would help cool prices on its own.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>the Fed meets in December for the final time in 2021. The big thing to watch for is whether Powell decides to reduce those bond purchases more quickly in order to quell inflation fears.</p>
</div>

style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eGood morning. \u003c/strong\u003eWe hope this email finds you exceedingly full, a little drowsy, Instead of doing a recap of yesterday’s news, which admittedly we didn’t pay much attention to, we’re going to do a deep dive on the economic topic du jour: inflation. Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nThe Inflation Situation: How We Got Here\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/11/23/the-inflation-situation-how-we-got-here?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" style=\"text-decoration:none;border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Balloons holding up money \" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/5d34b1dbb67b208244ef43a9ba72db2587dc3006-1500x1000.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe funny thing about the current inflation scare is...it all happened so \u003cem\u003eabruptly\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs the first Covid wave ripped through the US last spring, more than 20 million Americans lost their jobs and the country entered its worst recession in history. With GDP \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/19/its-official-the-covid-recession-lasted-just-two-months-the-shortest-in-us-history.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etumbling 31.4%\u003c/a\u003e in Q2 2020, the last thing worrying economists was surging prices. After all, for a brief moment, oil prices had just plummeted below $0.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut it turns out the worst recession in US history was also the shortest—by far. Thanks to government stimulus to the tune of nearly $6 trillion, many Americans were able to weather the storm and, flush with cash but restricted to their homes, went full \u003cem\u003eExtreme Makeover\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eConsider this: Consumer spending on goods was nearly \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/americans-spending-goods-versus-experiences-supply-chain-crisis-2021-10?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e26% higher\u003c/a\u003e in August 2021 than in January 2019.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eDemand is just one element of the price equation\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd while demand for goods skyrocketed, supply was not ready to meet it. For a number of reasons—frequent Covid lockdowns in Asia, widespread labor shortages, poor planning—producers were unable to make and ship enough goods to satisfy the ravenous appetites of consumers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo given this severe demand–supply imbalance, prices started to climb, slowly at first in late 2020 but then really picking up steam as the ball dropped on 2021. The consumer price index, which monitors the prices of a basket of consumer goods, grew 1.7% annually in February but by May had \u003ca href=\"https://www.bls.gov/charts/consumer-price-index/consumer-price-index-by-category-line-chart.htm?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ejumped 5%\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe higher inflation readings in spring 2021 were attributed to a few items that had an outsized impact on rising prices. You might remember all the fuss about used cars, which accounted for \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/05/12/inflation-rising-economy-weird?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emore than one-third\u003c/a\u003e of the monthly price increases in June. This weird dynamic lent ammo to the officials, Fed Chair Jerome Powell included, who argued that inflation was “transitory” and likely to subside once a few pandemic wrinkles had been ironed out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut Team Transitory is on the back foot right now. This fall, inflation has spread from used cars and energy to items across the economy, from rents to food to apparel. At the same time, wages are surging, which is great for workers but also contributes to inflation, as companies must raise prices on their products to offset higher labor costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIn October, consumer prices rose at their fastest pace in 31 years, and economists are still debating when inflation will peak.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo that’s how we got here.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable src=\"https://images.morningbrew.com/gif/2021-11-24/image-efda587fa20d01d0069a32696b082c1d614e1ef6-398x255-gif/giph.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eNot a dumb question at all. In fact, many economists \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/opinion/articles/2021-11-16/higher-inflation-why-do-economists-dislike-it-so-much?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehave trouble\u003c/a\u003e explaining exactly why inflation is so harmful.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eLet’s start here: Inflation is \u003cem\u003egood\u003c/em\u003e, when it grows slowly. The Fed targets a 2% rate of inflation over the long run, allowing for a few temporary blips.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eModerate inflation is a sign of a healthy economy. When consumers expect prices to increase in the future, they want to buy goods \u003cem\u003enow\u003c/em\u003e. Producers take this demand as a sign that they should make more goods, hire more labor, make more investments, etc., which generates a “virtuous” cycle of growth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAnd while inflation does mean higher prices for consumers, it also leads to higher salaries, blunting its effects on your wallet.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eLast quarter, wages \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/business-wages-salaries-increase-8ce98ea3bcc14c4810eb5a1111e1df49?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ejumped the most\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in 20 years of record-keeping.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eOkay, so when is inflation bad?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen higher prices outstrip wage growth, that’s bad, obviously, because your standard of living falls. Inflation is especially harmful to folks whose income is more fixed—like many seniors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eInflation, when left unchecked, can also escalate quickly. As we mentioned before, inflation messes with the human brain. As workers grow concerned about rising prices, they push for higher wages, which in turn raises costs for businesses, which forces them to hike prices, and...lather, rinse, repeat. This is called the “wage–price spiral,” and it led to consumer prices rising more than 14% annually in 1980.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFinally, higher inflation is bad because it typically doesn’t end well. In a bid to stop the spiraling inflation of the 1970s, then-Fed Chair Paul Volcker cranked up interest rates to slow down the economy, a necessary action that inevitably resulted in a punishing recession.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs we’ll discuss a little later, current Fed leaders have a tough task ahead of them in trying to rein in inflation without hitting the brakes on economic growth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" \n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThis chart from the White House shows the \u003ca href=\"https://www.whitehouse.gov/cea/blog/2021/07/06/historical-parallels-to-todays-inflationary-episode/?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esix major inflationary episodes\u003c/a\u003e following World War II, as measured by the consumer price index (CPI) and personal consumption expenditures (PCE), which is the Fed’s preferred inflation gauge. Let’s briefly explore each episode.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e1946–1948: \u003c/strong\u003eIn the years following WWII, inflation jumped more than 20% due to the scrapping of wartime price controls, surging consumer demand, and supply shortages.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e1950–1951: \u003c/strong\u003eThe Korean War spurred a rush for goods, while some production pivoted back to military material.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e1969–1971: \u003c/strong\u003eGDP growth averaged a whopping 4.8% during this period of economic expansion, which also resulted in higher inflation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e1973–1982: \u003c/strong\u003eTwo shocks to energy markets (an OPEC oil embargo and conflicts in the Middle East) led to the longest stretch of inflation in US history.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e1989–1991: \u003c/strong\u003eAnother war in the Middle East, the Gulf War, caused gas prices to spike.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e2008: \u003c/strong\u003eOil prices jumped to $140/barrel in July 2008, double what they had been a year earlier. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat can we learn? \u003c/strong\u003eWhile each inflationary period has its own unique characteristics, White House economists argue that our current situation most closely parallels the post-WWII bump in prices, which resulted from pent-up consumer demand and supply chain disruptions, and not 1970s-style inflation, which stemmed from extraordinary shocks to energy markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS style=\"text-decoration:none;border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"A shoulders-up photo of Fed Chair Jerome Powell looking off into the distance\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eSarah Silbiger/Getty collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWith inflation at its highest level since 1990, pressure is \u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/article/business-economy-prices-inflation-jerome-powell-583029ed34f028d4950fd5b0d896388f?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003emounting\u003c/a\u003e on the central bank to channel Mr. Freeze and cool down prices.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat would that look like? \u003c/strong\u003eWinding down its pandemic-era stimulus measures more aggressively. The central bank has already started to taper the $120 billion/month in bond purchases it began last summer, but some economists, such as Harvard’s Jason Furman, think the Fed should \u003ca href=\"https://www.piie.com/sites/default/files/documents/furman-2021-11-17.pdf?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003espeed up\u003c/a\u003e the wind-down in a bid to stop price growth in its tracks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eSome Fed officials agree. St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said recently, “It makes sense to try to move a little bit more hawkishly here and try to manage the inflation risk.”\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut it’s not that simple. Remember, the Fed changed its policy framework in 2020 that allows it to overshoot its 2% inflation target in the short term to achieve “maximum employment,” the idea that anyone who is willing and able to work has the opportunity to get a job.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd while the unemployment rate has dropped more quickly than expected (it’s down to 4.6% from a 14.7% peak in May 2020), the economy remains 5 million jobs short of its pre-pandemic levels.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eSo the Fed is in a \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-11-19/fed-s-powell-fights-high-inflation-in-his-1970-s-paul-volcker-moment?sref=vuYGislZ\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereally tricky position\u003c/a\u003e. It knows people are anxious about inflation, but also that the labor market is not fully healed. Reducing its bond purchases more aggressively, then immediately hiking interest rates afterward, could slow the economy before it’s totally recovered.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePlus, there are signs that the supply chain crunch is beginning to ease, which would help cool prices on its own.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003ethe Fed meets in December for the final time in 2021. The big thing to watch for is whether Powell decides to reduce those bond purchases more quickly in order to quell inflation fears.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS
